subject: Entrepreneurship
title: Values on the Wall vs. Values in the Hall
description: A short lesson to help you apply Values on the Wall vs. Values in the Hall.

hook.text: Enron's values were 'Integrity, Communication, Respect, Excellence.' Then they committed history's largest fraud.

buildup.text: Every company has stated values. Very few have lived values. The gap between them is where culture dies.

discovery.text: Lived values show in who gets promoted, who gets fired, and what behavior is rewarded under pressure.

twist.text: Patrick Lencioni says core values should make some people uncomfortable. If everyone agrees, they're too generic.

climax.text: Patagonia's value of environmentalism led them to sue the U.S. government. That's a real value in action.

punchline.text: Real values cost you something. The rest is decoration.

quiz.question: How can you tell if a company's values are real?
options: They are printed on posters in every office
They show in promotions, firings, and decisions under pressure
All employees can recite them from memory
